Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is designed to develop a program in renewable energy that targets two-year college students and includes as options an Associate Degree in Applied Science and a one-year Certificate of Completion. The program focuses primarily on photovoltaic (PV) and solar thermal systems, but also includes an overview of other renewable energy sources. The focus on solar systems is critical because there is significant potential for solar energy development in the El Paso, Texas region. The renewable energy program prepares students for entry-level positions in the field of PV and Solar Thermal installation and maintenance. The program also strengthens pathways for secondary school students by providing high school faculty development and instructional resources. Activities include curriculum development, two-year college faculty development, and student recruitment.

The overall goal of the project is to increase the number of El Paso area technicians who are well-prepared for entry-level positions in the emerging field of renewable energy. The project has three objectives:
1: To develop a state-approved one year certificate and two-year associate of applied science degree in renewable energy.
2: To build the capacity of college and partnering high school faculty to provide relevant and up-to-date education in the renewable energy field.
3: To respond to local employer needs in the emerging field of renewable energy by facilitating an active advisory committee of composed of business, industry, and education leaders.

Intellectual Merit: The new program provides students with opportunities for entry-level training in a field that is expected to grow and develop. The courses within the program are also accessible to students and incumbent workers in the electrical, construction, and plumbing fields. The program provides marketable skills and training leading to an industry recognized, entry level certificate as well as a certificate or degree from the college. The college is assessing the success of the program, with the possibility of developing additional advanced courses in the future. An industry advisory committee assists in ensuring that the program remains current and relevant in terms of new technology, consumer demands, and industry standards. Partnerships with secondary schools build a pathway for students, including articulated credit. The program offers hands on, practical experience for students who plan to work in the field or continue on to additional education.

Broader Impacts: For security, sustainability and economic reasons, state, federal, and municipal governments are assessing solar energy options. Employment opportunities in the field are expanding, particularly as new technologies are developed and consumer demand increases. This renewable energy program provides the college with the opportunity to act as a catalyst for economic growth in the region through the creation of new degree program and training opportunities for residents. The program is increasing the number of Hispanic students entering the renewable energy field because the college is a Hispanic serving institution and over 85% of the students are Hispanic.

Project Outcomes Report

This Project Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award.  Any opinions findings and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation: NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

The goal of the El Paso Community College (EPCC), Renewable Energy project, was to develop an Associate of Applied Science Degree (AAS) and a Certificate of Completion in Renewable Energy Technology at EPCC. The AAS program at EPCC was established with 45 technical course credits and 15 general education courses credits. The Level 2 Certificate of Completion includes 43 technical course credits and three general education course credits. Also, the EPCC Advanced Technology Center (ATC) created the PV Installers Level 1 Certificate of Completion that consists of 26 technical credit courses.  

Intellectual Merit:

The new program will provide students with opportunities for entry-level training in a field that is expected to grow and develop.  The courses within the program will also be accessible to students and incumbent workers in the electrical, construction, and plumbing fields.  The program will provide marketable skills and training leading to an industry-recognized entry-level certificate as well as a certificate or degree from EPCC.  EPCC intends to assess the success of the entry-level program, with the possibility of developing additional advanced courses in the future.  Formation of an industry advisory committee will assist in ensuring that the program stays up-to-date and relevant in terms of new technology, consumer demands, and industry standards.  Partnerships with secondary schools will build a pathway for students including articulated credit.  The program will offer hands-on, practical experience for students who plan to work in the field or continue on to additional education. 

The Sustainable Energy curriculum was designed to meet the needs of the El Paso regions energy industry; ensuring the success of students and providing a quality workforce for the green technology field. In June of 2016, the Texas Higher Education Coordinating Board as well Department of Education approved a 2 Level Certificate of Completion, one-year Certificate of Completion and the two-year Associate of Applied Science Degree in Renewable Energy Technology to be eligible for Financial Aid.

The AAS and Level 2 Certificate in Renewable Energy program began Fall 2016. Additionally, the Level 1 PV Installer Certificate is anticipated to start in Spring of 2018. The successful collaboration with four school districts and Job Corp developed a program that provides accessible training to students and incumbent workers in the electrical, heating & ventilation, construction, and plumbing fields.  The program includes preparation leading to an industry-recognized Entry-Level PV Installers, The North America Board of Certified Energy Practitioners (NABCEP) Certificate.  Additionally, an industry advisory committee was formed and established to assist in ensuring that the program stays up-to-date and relevant regarding new technology, consumer demands, and industry standards.  The program offers hands-on, practical experience for students who plan to work in the field or continue with their education.  The EPCC ATC students with this pathway national initiative will be receiving stackable credentials and industry-recognized certifications that will help them gain valuable learning experience and opportunities in the green field area.

Boarder Impacts:

Nationally, there is substantial interest in solar energy as a green economic engine.  For security, sustainability and economic reasons, state, federal, and municipal governments are assessing solar energy options.  The employment opportunities in the field will expand dramatically over the next few years, particularly as new technologies are developed and consumer demand increases.  The Renewable Energy program provides EPCC with the opportunity to act as a catalyst for economic growth in the El Paso area through the creation of new degree program and training opportunities for residents.  EPCC is a Hispanic serving institution and over 85% of our students are Hispanic, and many are economically disadvantaged and the first generation to attend college.  EPCC will increase the number of Hispanic students entering the renewable energy field. 

EPCC is a Hispanic serving institution with over 85% of the Hispanic population; many are economically disadvantaged, and the first generation to attend college. EPCC is increasing the number of the Hispanic student population by providing a Financial Aid approved program allowing more students to enroll.  During the first semester in 2016, 15 students enrolled in the program consisted of 14 males and one female, further break down into special populations such as two veterans, two displaced workers, and four first-generation students, and the remaining students were first-time students.  The number of Hispanic students enrolled in the program increased during the fall of 2017, where the program saw 28 students enrolled in the degree program.
